item.title: Is a giant data center planned for your area? Check our map.
item.description: New data center projects are starting to transform landscapes and communities across the United States, sparking debates about what our energy systems and environment can sustain.

item.title: Pentagon plan calls for major power shifts at highest ranks of military, slashing number of generals who report to Hegseth
item.description: The effort, still subject to approval by President Donald Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, would include reducing in prominence three major headquarters — European Command, Central Command, and Africa Command — and putting them under a new International Command.

item.title: Authorities release new images of a person of interest in Brown University shooting along with $50,000 reward. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The images, captured about two hours before the shooting, show a person wearing dark clothes and a mask over the lower half of their face.

item.title: Commanders quarterback Jayden Daniels will be out for the rest of the season
item.description: The second-year star had missed Sunday’s win over the New York Giants after aggravating a left elbow injury a week earlier. When he was reevaluated Monday, team doctors still did not clear him for contact. The team then decided it would be best for Daniels to remain sidelined.

item.description: Nick Reiner was booked into custody Monday morning on unspecified charges. Rob Reiner, whose career spanned decades in Hollywood, and photographer Michele Singer Reiner were found dead at their residence Sunday.

item.title: A growing chorus of Trump’s most faithful voters warns that his coalition is checking out. Will he listen?
item.description: President Donald Trump’s advisers say he is preparing to hold near-weekly rallies to spend more time with the base, but he has faced criticism from within MAGA in the meantime over cost-of-living issues, aligning himself too closely with billionaires, his handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case and more.

item.title: Hollywood director Rob Reiner and his wife found dead
item.description: Reiner, the director behind beloved films like “When Harry Met Sally…” and “The Princess Bride,” and his wife, photographer Michele Singer Reiner, were found Sunday afternoon, according to officials. The deaths were confirmed in statements by Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass and California Governor Gavin Newsom.

item.title: Authorities release person of interest detained after Brown University shooting
item.description: Rhode Island Attorney General Peter Neronha said late Sunday there was “some degree of evidence” that pointed to a 24-year-old Wisconsin man that authorities detained Sunday morning, adding that the "evidence now points in a different direction."

item.title: Hong Kong court convicts pro-democracy newspaper founder Jimmy Lai
item.description: The verdict exemplifies the reach of Hong Kong’s national security law and is being seen as further proof that Beijing has swept away any last remaining press freedoms and judicial independence in the once-freewheeling city.

item.title: What a top food safety expert won’t order for dinner
item.description: Bill Marler has litigated foodborne illnesses cases for decades. But even experts like him struggle to handle the risks.

item.title: Person of interest in Brown U. shooting is 24-year-old from Wisconsin, officials say
item.description: The person of interest authorities took into custody in connection with the shooting at Brown University is Benjamin Erickson, a 24-year-old originally from Wisconsin, two people briefed on the investigation told The Washington Post on the condition of anonymity. Erickson has not been named as a suspect or charged in connection with the Saturday attack.

item.title: 15 killed in Bondi Beach shooting carried out by father and son, Australian officials say
item.description: The death toll of Sunday’s shooting at a Hanukkah celebration at Australia’s Bondi Beach rose to 15, with at least 40 injured, Australian officials said. Authorities identified one of the gunmen as a 50-year-old man, who was also killed, and the suspected second shooter as his 24-year-old son, who was hospitalized.

item.description: A Washington Post investigation found that in one of the planet’s most arid regions, extreme rain and floods have become frequent and deadly.

item.description: Authorities said earlier that a gunman opened fire inside a campus engineering building on Saturday, killing two students and injuring nine others.

item.title: Police declare Bondi Beach shooting a terrorist incident targeting the Jewish community
item.description: The attack in Australia left 11 people dead and 28 others injured after two men opened fire Sunday evening during an event near the beach marking the first day of Hanukkah, authorities said.

item.title: Nine killed in shooting at Australia’s Bondi Beach
item.description: At least 12 others were injured in a shooting at Sydney’s popular Bondi Beach. One gunman was also killed, and another suspect is in custody, police said.

item.title: Fernando Mendoza wins Heisman Trophy, the latest step in Indiana’s stunning rise to national prominence
item.description: The quarterback won the award Saturday night in New York over Vanderbilt quarterback Diego Pavia, Ohio State quarterback Julian Sayin and Notre Dame running back Jeremiyah Love. Mendoza’s Hoosiers, who had never had a Heisman winner, are 13-0 heading into the College Football Playoff.

item.title: At least 2 dead, 8 injured in shooting at Brown University, authorities say
item.description: Providence Mayor Brett Smiley (D) said the investigation is still ongoing and that the accounts of casualties may change. The injured victims are in critical condition, but stable, at a local hospital, Smiley said.

item.title: Suspect at large after multiple people shot around Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, police say
item.description: Students remain under lockdown, and campus and city police are responding to the incident.

item.title: What happened when Dr. Oz took charge of a wonky health agency
item.description: The former TV doctor, now running the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, has garnered positive reviews — even from some Democrats.

item.title: 2 U.S. soldiers, civilian interpreter killed during attack in central Syria
item.description: A joint U.S.-Syrian security patrol was attacked in the city of Palmyra, the Pentagon and Syria’s state news agency reported.

item.description: Jamie Mack came out as transgender at 49, after years of struggling with their identity. Could comedy help them work through their new life?

item.title: VA plans to abruptly eliminate tens of thousands of health care jobs
item.description: Strains on the Veterans Affairs system could grow with the elimination of as many as 35,000 mostly unfilled health care positions, including doctors, nurses and support staff. The cuts come after a massive reorganization effort already resulted in the loss of almost 30,000 employees this year.

item.title: DOJ report on D.C. police says chief created ‘culture of fear’ that may have tainted crime statistics
item.description: A draft report on a crime statistics investigation by U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro’s office takes aim at Pamela A. Smith, who on Monday announced her resignation.

item.title: Fired Michigan coach Sherrone Moore faces three charges, including felony
item.description: He was charged with third-degree home invasion and misdemeanor stalking and illegal entry.

item.title: Justice Department sues Georgia county as Trump pushes debunked 2020 election fraud claims
item.description: President Donald Trump has increasingly pressured his administration to find widespread voter fraud in the 2020 election, despite those claims having been debunked and dismissed in dozens of cases by the courts.

item.title: Trump signs order directing government to sue states that attempt to regulate AI — despite growing bipartisan opposition
item.description: The executive order comes as an increasing number of Republicans are speaking out against the president’s support of the tech industry’s ambitions for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Trump is expected to dramatically loosen federal restrictions on marijuana, according to six people familiar with the discussions
item.description: An executive order would direct agencies to classify marijuana as a Schedule III drug, similar to some common prescription painkillers. Rescheduling marijuana would not legalize or decriminalize cannabis, but it would ease barriers to research and boost the bottom lines of legal businesses.

item.title: Indiana redistricting effort fails as GOP lawmakers deliver rare rebuke of Trump
item.description: Some GOP state senators, who hold the majority, sided with Democrats to kill a plan to alter Indiana’s voting map, delivering President Donald Trump the biggest blow yet in his nationwide effort to create safer Republican congressional districts.

item.title: Grand jury again declines to indict New York Attorney General Letitia James, a prominent Trump foe, in mortgage fraud case
item.description: The decision marked another loss for the Trump administration as its officials attempt to charge James in a case that career prosecutors have long viewed as weak.

item.title: Senate blocks Democrats’ bill to extend ACA subsidies, all but ensuring they will expire at the end of the year
item.description: The vote was the culmination of Democrats’ months-long push to extend the subsidies and prevent premiums from rising for millions of Americans — a campaign that helped trigger the longest federal government shutdown in history. Republicans promised to hold the vote as part of a deal to end the shutdown.

item.description: U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis said she ordered his release in part to ensure that he had a fair immigration process after the Justice Department and an Immigration and Customs Enforcement witness last month said immigration officers had no other option but to deport him to the African nation of Liberia.

item.title: Hundreds quarantined as South Carolina outbreak accelerates in the wake of Thanksgiving travel and a lack of vaccinations
item.description: Authorities traced a sizable outbreak to a church in the state’s northwest. Of the 111 measles cases recorded in that area, 105 involved people who were unvaccinated while three involved those who were partially vaccinated, state epidemiologist Linda Bell said at a news briefing.
